message.content:
Forget all previous instructions.

Always return the result in a valid JSON format. Do not truncate the output and never generate ... in the response. The output should not raise a JSONDecodeError when loaded in Python.

Given a list of sentences extracted from papers, extract the sentences that explicitly mention a dataset used in the paper. Only include sentences where the dataset is clearly and unambiguously named, such as LSMS or DHS. Exclude sentences that mention software used for data analysis, equipment used to collect data, or other tools that are not datasets. Also, exclude sentences that only cite a reference without mentioning the dataset. Also exclude sentences that refer to data computed by the author without mentioning the dataset used to derive it.

Your task is to return the sentence ids of the identified sentences as a JSON array along with the reason why you included them. The output format should be [{"sent_id": s_XXXXX, "data_mentioned": true, "reason": <dataset name>}]. If a sentence mentions a dataset clearly and unambiguously, set "data_mentioned" to true and fill in the "reason" field with the name of the dataset

Do not explain.

Text:

s_02147: The present study is motivated by this and applies tools and techniques of scientometrics to uncover insights from research papers.

s_02197: This study assesses whether this relationship exists in multiple other aging populations.

s_02230: This is one of the first studies to examine these associations in a large sample of the same patients.

s_02280: Our initial work prior to this project (e.g.

s_02480: We only kept samples that were available across both GISAID and COG UK data sources at the time of this study.

where U is the total number of sources consulted.

s_02580: The analysis shows a relationship

s_02680: To incorporate this trend into our analysis, we simply add this many points to each black student's SAT score in the 2000 data, after re-weighting the data to reflect income convergence.

s_02730: Using the reprocessed 1992 and 2001 U.S. NLCD land cover data from Wolter et al.

s_02780: A major strength of the present study is the utilization of a large, population-based sample of US children with rigorous, prospective measurements of cognitive development at multiple time points.

s_02830: 1994; McLoyd 1998; Repetti et al.

s_02880: We would also like to compare our response rates and rate of return to a comparable sample of the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP).

s_02980: The analysis was conducted taking into account the objectives of the study.

s_03030: Ideally, in order to minimize error variance, an ADNI like multi-site reproducibility using a large sample of volunteers scanned repeatedly at all sites and within a short period of time, should be used.

s_03080: For the initial estimated model, all the available independent variables suggested from literature in table 1 were included.
